case_title: CHALLA APPALASWAMY vs COMMISSIONER OF INCOME TAX, A. P.
respondant: COMMISSIONER OF INCOME TAX, A. P.
complaint_summary: The assessee-firm applied for registration under the Income Tax Act for assessment years 1960-61, 1961-62, and 1962-63, which was refused by the Income Tax authorities citing improper division of profits and losses.
investigation_summary: The Income Tax Appellate Tribunal upheld the refusal of registration, stating that the firm divided profits and losses separately for two businesses instead of combining them as per the partnership deed.
judgment_summary: The High Court ruled that the refusal of registration was incorrect. It held that the division of profits and losses was consistent with the partnership deed and did not contravene legal provisions. The court answered the referred question in favor of the assessee.
Decision_or_verdict: Question answered in the negative and in favor of the assessee.
legal_arguments: Defense argued that the division of profits and losses was lawful and consistent with the partnership deed.
Prosecution argued that the division was not in accordance with the shares specified in the partnership deed.
sections: Section 66(1) of Indian Income Tax Act, 1922
Section 256(1) of Indian Income Tax Act, 1961
Section 26-A of Indian Income Tax Act, 1922
citations: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Sivakasi Match Exporting Co. (1964) 53 ITR 204
S. C. Prashar v. Vasantsen Dwarkadas (1983) 49 ITR (SC) 1
Commissioner of Income Tax v. S. M. Chaitnavis (1932) 2 Comp. Cas. 464
Calcutta Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax (1959) 37 ITR 1
key_issues: Whether the refusal of registration to the assessee-firm was justified.
Interpretation of clauses in the partnership deed regarding profit and loss sharing.

legal_terms.Instrument of Partnership: A legal document specifying the terms and conditions of a partnership.
legal_terms.Registration of Firm: Process under tax law to recognize a firm for tax purposes.

words_and_phrases.Regardless of such losses: Phrase indicating that a minor partner is entitled to profits but not liable for losses.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the refusal of registration to an assessee-firm due to alleged improper division of profits and losses. The High Court ruled in favor of the assessee, interpreting the partnership deed clauses as lawful and consistent with the Indian Partnership Act.
